newsitem.title: USA: Westinghouse loss narrows in quarter.
newsitem.headline: Westinghouse loss narrows in quarter.

text.p: Westinghouse Electric Corp. said Friday its losses narrowed in the first quarter as the company's robust CBS Radio group helped offset weakness at its television and industrial businesses.

The company said it lost $151 million, or 23 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with a loss of $181 million, or 41 cents a share, in the 1996 period. Excluding one-time items, the year-earlier loss was $114 million, or 26 cents a share.
Including Infinity Broadcasting, acquired at the end of last year, sales rose 18 percent to $2.2 billion.
Infinity's contribution to earnings was offset by weakness at the company's television network, caused by poor ratings and the way it had to account for program rights.
Westinghouse's media group earned $110 million before interest, taxes and other items, unchanged from the 1996 period.
Sales at CBS Radio surged 18 percent, far outperforming the overall industry. Pretax earnings soared 38 percent to $91 million.

"Radio was spectacular, and I think that reflects strong management and superb assets," said analyst John Reidy at Smith Barney. "They significantly outperformed the industry by three or four percentage points in terms of revenues."
At the CBS TV network, earnings fell due to lower audience levels in key demographic categories and higher costs associated with sports and special events.
Television revenues slid 4 percent on a same-station basis. Last year's first-quarter results got a boost from political advertising ahead of the 1996 elections.
Earnings fell at Westinghouse's other media businesses, which include Eyemark and CBS Cable -- formerly Group W Satellite Communications.

The industrial businesses lost $59 million, compared with a $1 million loss excluding special charges in the year-ago period. About $50 million of the loss in the latest period was from re-evaluation of a global energy project, it said.

Operating losses at Power Systems, which includes Power Generation and Energy Systems, grew due to delays in international project closings. Year-ago earnings were also boosted by a large nuclear fuel reload order.

Operating profit at Thermo King, a refrigerated transport unit, grew 4 percent. Westinghouse said profits were enhanced by last year's European acquisitions, lower material costs and greater productivity. Orders rose 5 percent due to a large container order and strong service parts business.
Westinghouse stock fell 62.5 cents to $17.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
